Does anyone know what the backend tests in travis would fail for this? How can I rerun the test without making a new PR? @AllisonWang I'm tagging you because I see you're on the maintainers team and have been active in PRs recently.. Hope that's okay
@criccomini Can you review it, when you have time?

If I understood your point about try number correctly (i.e. you don't like the idea of adding it to the task_instance table), then I really, really feel try number is critical to Airflow regardless (we were talking about it with Alex/Max internally + having a separate table that stores all task instance tries append-only).

Here is the expert from my mailing list email in case you missed it.
```

The concept of "attempt" is needed regardless of logging, the way retries are stored/handled right now is not very sane.
- Old TI state is permanently deleted
- In the task logs you get "Try 1/6"... 2/6... 3/6... 1/6... 2/6 in logs which doesn't make sense (if it's the Nth time the task is running it should be logged as the Nth time). I recall other strange behaviors in these log lines too (maybe something like Try 4/3).
- The "primary key" for a task instance run is not complete (which is what Allison's logging change needs), you could say that TaskInstance should only keep track of the latest TaskInstance run, but we still want to store all tries for a task instance somewhere in the database, and we still need to key this off of "attempt".
```
I don't like start_dates, there aren't really guarantees around them being completely unique (which try_number gives us for free), they are a poor approximation for a unique key. Feel free to reply to the open source thread and we can discuss along with Max/Alex/other committers though.

Hi @aoen my main issue is that this information should not be stored in the `task_instance` table but rather in a `task_instance_log` table. Which is your append only table. My suggestion of a primary key on `'task_id, dag_id, execution_date, start_date'` is the same as having a `try_number` in this table which you should be storing anyway.

So attempt/try_number yes, but not how it is done now. Storing it in the task_instance table doesn't make logically sense. If you want to store the count of attempt/tries it should be named `total_tries/total_attempts` if you don't want to do aggregation or a `max(start_date)`
You're changing the behavior of the endpoint, and at this point it doesn't match the docstring, and in fact, does the opposite.

@saguziel i didn't get when you said it does the opposite. This bug fix shows the last run values of dag that is missing from the current version. Can you please give me some screenshots of code or UI that can elaborate more?

Ah I see, I think I agree (need to see the complete new schema to be sure), but that's a little bit more involved. We should be able to easily migrate from the current version to this new one, we have still made forward progress (most of Allison's logic will stay).
The behavior doesn't match with the docstring, nor with any of the upstreams (see also latest_dag_runs in api.experimental)
It's not really a bug fix when the behavior of that column was that it would show the execution_date of the latest running dag_run.
But perhaps the documentation doesn't make it clear. We can go that route, but either way, this change on its own is not complete.

@bolkedebruin PTAL. GCS Task handler is added and read method signature is slightly changed. I've created a JIRA [AIRFLOW-1454](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1454) and several sub-tasks for improving airflow logging. Please feel free to modify and/or add more tasks.

I think the tests need to be updated as well
I think this change seems reasonable, but please use the standard PR format

+1 

Really, no one is interested in this feature? This PR has just a few lines changed and is easy to review.
To play devil's advocate for a moment, what's the advantage of this over setting a very short timeout for sensors with a large retry count and using the retry delay as the "sleep" interval?

So this is legitimate, but shifts some of the burden of slot utilization towards other costs like more task startups and more communication overhead. These costs may be preferable depending on the scenario/environment. Starting a task can have significant overhead depending on the size of the DAG and other factors that depend on the executor. Say for the upcoming Kubernetes executor, startup may include booting up a docker instance and doing a shallow clone of the repo.

Since this is a major change, I would argue that we shouldn't change the current default since organizations have provisioned and stabilized their environments based on the current behavior. Default behavior could be changed when moving to `2.0`, which isn't really planned or scheduled at the moment.

Another idea around reducing the overall sensor slot utilization would be to move that burden towards the scheduler (let's call it the supervisor now since it does more than just scheduling at this point). My idea there was to add a flag to `BaseSensorOperator` that would tell the scheduler to run the poke method in line with the scheduling instead of using the executor. In that scenario, there's no startup cost and no communication overhead. The downside is that it can slow down the scheduler. This would be a great option where sensing is cheap and fast

That gives us potentially 3 `sensor_mode`s, which I would argue should be implemented as a BaseOperator feature. Derivative classes can decide to expose the argument or force it. Administrator can also use the `policy` function to force certain sensing mode in certain or all contexts in their environment.

> what's the advantage of this over setting a very short timeout for sensors with a large retry count and using the retry delay as the "sleep" interval?

I would argue that there are cases that we would like to distinguish between `sleep` and `failure`. For example:

* We may have a sensor that senses two files: `SUCCESS` and `FAILURE`, when `SUCCESS` is present, the sensor succeeds, when `FAILURE` is present, the sensor fails, and when none are present, the sensor sleeps.
* We may have an API operator that submits a certain command to a remote API service. Afterwards, it starts polling for the running state of that command. When the remote server says it's still running, the API operator goes to sleep, when the remote server says the command has failed, the API operator submits again for a fixed amount of retries, and when the re-submit retries exhausted, the API operator fails.

@jhsenjaliya 

> It would be nice to just be able to switch hooks (ftp->sftp) and have the same interface/functionality.

I was actually working on the SFTPHook in the philosophy of the FTPHook in fact... :)

> In my case I need other features needed by the ftp hook for SFTP.
> Sure, that would be good flexibility to have, but Paramiko is all about secure connections using ssh trasport, and dont support ftp or ftp over SSL/TLS. Although since it provides most of standard ftp functions in its sftp implementation ( ex: getCWD() ), we can create wrapper functions in SFTPOperator, if the compatibility and easy switching between ftp and sftp is needed. That would be a separate change though and out of the scope of this PR.

The problem is then standardize the semantics of a hook and an operator. This has been in fact confusing for me when I started using Airflow.
I am tempted to rework both FTP and SFTP functionality but that implies another change of mindset for those using one or the other because we have now a FTPHook providing some needed functionality (and managing such FTP connection), and then a SFTPOperator providing some other functionality in a different way (for example, the get/put 'methods').
And as many said they would like to be able to have similar interfaces (for example, in the scenario of moving from FTP to SFTP).
Personally listing the contents of a directory is key for our work (we list, filter based on some rules, and then retrieve some subset of the list of files depending on those rules).

I am happy to put a PR with our custom changes on this but I wonder if this would be ok with the Airflow maintainers and @jhsenjaliya? (To basically do another makeover of the FTP/SFTP functionality in another PR)
